Review Text: nice small railway station very close to the market place and centrally located in ella ,need to buy a platform ticket to enter , train ride kandy or nuveralia to ella is a must .

A small station but no stairs that you have to lug your luggage over which was really nice.  Gets very busy outside the station with almost no parking available.  Lovely station that looks cared for.  Go for a walk on the tracks from here to 9 arch bridge, obviously checking for trains first, but very pleasant walk. Announcements very clear for incoming trains.  Has a bathroom to the right as you enter the station.  Remember to keep your tickets as they do check these when you try and leave the station.

Take a train from Ella to Badulla, pass the Nine Arches and photos out of the side of the train. Make sure you hold on tight though! I found Ella to be quite pleasant although the traffic was a bit on the messy side. Be careful of the accommodation you  book as a lot of them may require a bit of climbing. Lots of activities around Ella, so have fun! Some great restaurants there but only picture of one, try it!
Great experience of local railways, beautiful countryside, friendly staff; colonial in feel and rolling stock likely from same era…..very memorable.

Our group's 'Viceroy Special' train paused here for many minutes to cross (meet) a mixed train (with freight wagons and at the rear, passenger carriages). The station was clean and well looked after. There is at least one kiosk. As usual in Sri Lanka for all but the smallest stations, it is staffed whenever trains are timetabled to stop for passengers.
Amazing trip on the train up into the hills for such a small fee. If you're in Sri Lanka you must catch the train through the countryside it's unbelievable.

Amazing positive experience on train station in Ella. I lost my wallet at the station in Ella and I got it back the next day, thank's to a very kind station master. Very satisfied with the service and honesty of all employees on the station.

Review Title: Unpleasant staff working at the place, but a nice building architecture
Review Text: If you are getting off at this train stop, take a picture of your ticket. There is a person collecting the tickets from all the passengers when they are leaving the train station. I didn't know that, asked the guy collecting the tickets if I can keep mine as a present, but the guy was unpleasant, didn't even look at me, showing me to leave. I see this place totally prepared for and welcoming tourists. The railway station itself is a nice and historical building. If you enjoy things like that, I recommend to visit the in-between train arrivals. Otherwise the place is too crowded and you just move on your way to the exit with everyone else.
Well maintained railway station. Nicely signposted for the carriages. Announcements can actually be understood!

Review Title: Visiting the station after many years
Review Text: Ella has become a very popular destination with the tourists in Sri Lanka. The railway station serves as a major gateway facilitating travel to the popular city.  The station is well maintained and the staff in attendance barring the SM were quite helpful to share details of the attractions nearby. .
The station is well organised and clean with plenty of travellers using its facilities.  One of the better stations in Sri Lanka.
Its maintained well. Other stations should do the same as Ella station. It looks really good, credit should go the station master.

I visited the station as the outside look was amazing. I wanted to go inside and check, but the Officials said no as there was no train coming at that time. They said the platform ticket can be issued only during a trian's arrival time. HHHHMmmm... not only he said that he was very sarcastic about our request.....Strange.......
You have to get off this station to see Nine Arch at Ella. You never forget this place ever when you visit Ella ❤️

Built by the British a 100 years ago (1918) the Ella Railway Station (ERS) has original colonial era architecture and is easily one of the most visited single-track mainline railway stations in Sri Lanka. Irrespective of which way you travel from ERS absolute scenic beauty is guaranteed. Travel the 20 km’s towards Badulla (the end of upcountry railway track) and you will ride over the Nine Arch Bride and Pass the Demodara Railway Loop. Ride in the opposite direction towards Idalgashinna Railway Station also 20 km’s away and you will enjoy spectacular views of tea plantations and sleepy mountainous villages. Generally 4 trains pass by ERS during the day and tickets are issued only a short while before each train arrives so make sure to be at the station ahead of time to secure your ticket. There is also a safe vehicle parking area besides the station in case you have to leave behind the vehicle you drive/ride. A lessor known fact is that Sri Lanka Railways (and of course the ERS) is one of the last remaining railway’s in the world to continue to use Edward Tyer's century and half old ingenious tablet signalling system, while other countries have gone on to adopt more advanced radio and electronic signalling methods. If you are interested to take a look at the ‘key token instrument’ get to the station before the rush and have a friendly chat with the station master….I hope he will oblige your request (well I have not asked my self though!)
It is basically a normal train ride, like we had many years ago in Europe, packed with people, music, different faces and different smells. If you miss it, you can take the ride.
Arrived here at night. Gorgeous little station and easy to pick up a tuktuk outside or walk the short walk into the town

Booked a train ride (Viceroy II) from Ella to Kandy, so got to visit this little railway station. Staff service was ok, used the wheelchair for a friend who hurt her leg to wheel her from entrance to the platform. The train arrival was on time -- plus point to such service in Sri Lanka! Enjoyed the ride with the beautiful scenery along the way (6+ hours), mostly tea plantations, valleys, villages, towns, also the historical design of each small stations along the way! The ride was pretty shaky at times (due to the rail), haha.

Adorable train station to enjoy before you go on the most beautiful train ride in the world!  The station manager is friendly and helpful, there is an ATM there and lots of Tuk drivers if you wish to avoid the short 1 block walk to town.

The train journey is must to do while in Sri Lanka. If you do not have much time then shorten ur train trip. But this is like must. Train with open doors. Train offering amazing views of lush green forests. Get the train tickets earlier & do not get 1st class ticket, get 2nd or 3rd class.

The train ride between Kandy and Ella is certainly something you cannot and should not miss. And one of the best part of this train ride is to witness the small, quaint and antique looking railways stations on the way. Let it be hatton, nuwara eliya or Ella. We loved all these small railways stations as much as we loved the train ride. They gave us a feeling of living 40-50 years back in time. The station is very basic but it's in the middle of the nature and you gotta take a picture in front of the train when it is stopped here. Usually the train driver and the station master do not mind tourists taking such pictures but it's always good to ask for permission before jumping on the tracks.
My partner and I traveled through the hill country to Ella where our driver picked us up. When the train arrives it’s busy at the station. Plenty of decent restaurants alongside the station.
Ella Railway Station is 10 min drive by taxi from the City center. There are not so many trains daily going to Colombo or Kandy each day. The Station is well maintained.

Did anybody make the same experience? When buying train tickets at Ella Station we did not get the right change back (3700 instead of 3800 Rs). Not a big deal we thought until we met an Australian guy on the platform afterwards who got only 3050 back instead of 3500. By accident or systematic?
When in Sri Lanka, it is a must to do the most scenic train trip in the world. Ella is a great place to start, if heading back towards Kandy.
Easy to get to station from town , quick on and off from the train with plenty of Tuk tuks just waiting to take you to your accommodation,
Clean and friendly, we were able to upgrade to 2nd class as we arrived very early for our train to Colombo.
Nice colonial style buildings with friendly staff. Well maintained and beautiful. There are well maintained toilet facilities. The station has a lovely view of the surroundings.
How cool was their to transit from down south to nuwara Eliya.cool mist Breez refresh for better rest

We arrived in Ella by train and were surprised to find the area around the station populated by very groovy cafes and stalls. Good vibe. Like all stations we saw on the Tea Train it was clean and decorated with flower posts and colonial charm
This railway station clearly has large numbers of passengers.  It provides basic facilities for travellers.  However more is available nearby

We went for a walk along the tracks from this quaint old station.  As per all the reviews and suggestions, ignore the sign that says do not walk on the tracks. Had a great walk - met a few others on the tracks. Really beautiful walk.

The train station is easy to find. Friendly and efficient staff. They inform passengers if there are delays by posting notices on the ticket office window. We were not able to use toilet facilities at the train station but there are many cafes closeby. We were lucky to watch a cricket match is is right by the station. ONE CANNOT BUY TICKETS WHEN THERE ARE POWERCUTTS WHICH HAPPENS ALMOST EVERYDAY- SO CHECK IF THERE IS ELECTRICITY BEFORE GOING TO THE STATION. Sometimes they ask for your passport.

Pretty pretty railway station.  plenty of flowers and Olive tree ..........  my family & I were allowed to just sit there to rest on our return from Hikes without platform tickets ...... Siriwardene was a nice guy .....

It is just the station, however it is common that people go to Ella by long train ride. We had the ride from Nuwara Eliya. It was extremely crowded train, crowded by locals and more tourists, and it was so funny experience, and the views along the way were pretty.

Obviously, this review is not about a station, but about a journey from Nani Oya to Ella by train. Tickets are quite hard to come by and it is better to ask a travel agent to get them for you as reserved seats go on sale 30 days before the date and have to be picked up in person. I would also advise taking first class seats because you have more space to move around and see the views. Our tickets cost 1000 rupees each, less than £5 for a two and a half hour journey. The views are fabulous: waterfalls, hills, cliffs, paddy fields, tea plantations, small villages and tiny railway halts decorated with scores of flower pots. Just sit back, Elam and enjoy the views!
Pretty enough little railway station with some nice features but, fundamentally, just a railway station. Apparently it regularly wins the best kept station award, which is nice.
Do not take the taxi from there. Just walk. It is like..400 meters and you are in the city already. The taxi drives ask you 200-400 locals (1-2 euros) and it is pointless to pay.

As we arrived in Ella by Minibus we saved ourselves the joy of stepping out of the carriage onto the platform at this station. A much better experience was seeing it from the railway lines as we walked from the Nine Arches Bridge. Signs do say not to walk on the railway lines but the view of the building trackside and without the mad rush experienced by others was more meaningful.
Its a standard Sri Lanka Railway station, busy with a horde of tourists.  Interestingly the locals, tourists and officials all ignore to 'Prohibited to walk on Tracks' signs....as did we

Be in time if you want to book train tickets. Long queus and waiting times. Prepare your train travels in general and book tickets ahead if you want granted a seat, otherwise you will have to stay up. We went from Ella to Haputale to visit Lipton Seat. This was only one hour travel but as always train over crowded. It us a special experience so do go by train! Book first class tickets long time before your travel schedule.
The place is old and uninteresting - the toilet is dirty - be prepared. We came by train and also walked from 9 arches

Understanding and being understood can be difficult. We traveled from Ella to Bandula just to experience the train. I understand the train can be very highly rated. I am sorry to say I do not agree. It was overcrowded and rough by 3rd class and difficult to see any of the view. There are 2 types of trains one red and one blue I believe the red is the roughest class and that is what I road. You may have a better experience on the blue.

Get there early, sharpen your elbows and chuck British politeness out of the window. Alternatively risk standing for 7 hours, on a beautiful, but hot, jolty train, squished in with tourists and locals alike. We were lucky, we arrived an hour before and got a set of tickets. Mrs Johnson was tasked with seat grabbing. She is a habbbitual London commuter, so her area of expertise. Me with, our two rucksacks, was to follow on. Great made plans of mice and men will often go awry, and the train door to the 2nd class carriage stopped but feet away from me, leaving Mrs J blindsided. A scrabble emerged, my weight of 100kg plus two 25kg bags, front and rear, made a formidable force, sending many Europeans flying as I entered the train behind one other. And thank god I did, we got the last two seats and therefore secured our tenure for the 7 hours to Kandy. The view is beautiful. If you can, sit on the right hand side from Ella to Nuwara Elliya and the left side thereafter to Kandy, if you are fortunate enough to have a choice. You will get views in any case if you don't get that option, but for full exposure this is the best way to do it. A string of merchants peddling everything from fresh fruit to deep fried salty snacks push through, baskets on their heads, malevolently scolwing at the tourists they scatter on their mission, followed shortly by yet more chaps with cold drinks and coffee. Don't think for one moment that the exit at Kandy is any easier, as this isn't the last stop, Colombo is. Therefore, as you are pulling yourself from 7 hours in a jauntilly angled chair, you will be ambushed left right and centre as the train stops, by those wishing to secure your perch for the next leg. A mad scrabble ensued, made easier by my significant belly of 21 days rice, curry and Lion Larger and we landed, unceremoniously, on the platform, to a throng of delighted tuk tuk drivers waiting for us and therefore their next fare. One tip, overheard from a man with an impressive beard and even more impressive shirt: take a tuk tuk an hour or so from Ella, they are cheap so no concern there, to the origination point of the train, Badulla. Far from the madding throng of tourists, you will be guaranteed not only a seat, but a choice of seat and no fisty cuffs with fellows at Ella Station. You will also sail over the acclaimed nine arch Bridge, therefore adding another layer of excellence to this already exciting journey.

We took the scenic train from Ella to Nuwara Eliya. It's totally reminiscent of the green trains in old day China, from the small scenic train station, to the punchable tickets, to the peddlers getting on and off in between stations. Brings back childhood memories.

Nice and clean station, be early to catch a ticket and a nice seat. Schedule is shown outside of the station and keep your ticket, you need to show on your final destination, otherwise you have to pay a fine.
Place to get boarded on famous Ella-Kandy train ride. Nothing exceptional great, just cute little station with amazing hill views.
If you visit to ella little adam's peak,you want to travel by train journey and end to it ella railway station then you can achive your travel goals in sri lanka.

I wouldn't go all the way to Ella just to see this train station.  However, since we were traveling from Kandy to Ella on the train, we had to go to this station.  It is a very small quant little station with some English charm.  You can imagine what this station was like in old colonial times.  Once we got off the train, we only stayed for a few minutes to take a couple pictures. The station platform was fairly crowded once all the passengers got off the train.
... though you can start from there to go to Ella Rock or to the nine arches' bridge.  This is just a station :-)
It's a must.  Super cute and picturesque like something out of a children's book.  Beware, double check the dates on your train ticket.

The main transport hub in and out of Ella. It’s quaint and they try to keep it well maintained. If getting train tickets, go for third class reserved. It’s more than adequate you have guaranteed seats and great views. Try and book in advance though if you want the 9.24 departure. Turning right along the tracks from Ella station will take you to nine arch bridge. The Kandy train doesn’t cross it- you have to carry on to Badulla if you want to do that. There are toilets here as well.

A little bit of England in the style of the railway stationreminicent of the country railway stations in UK. Neatly kept with some developments in progress to deal with the increasing number of tourist. Recieving and handing the Railway tablet is not seen inmany parts of the world and the station master can make a feature out of this.
We caught the train from Ella through the tea country.  This is a quaint little railway station with lots of character.  Lots of car parking there too and quite close to the Ella township

Although our destination was Ella, our guide advised we stay on the train to its terminus about a half hour beyond Ella, allowing us to go over the famous Nine Arch Bridge on the train and see other spectacular sites as well.  If you have a way to get back to Ella (tuk tuk or whatever) we'd advise traveling at least one stop beyond Ella for the views, then returning.
Cute little station amongst the mountains. Looks like in a old British movie. Totally colonial style.
The  old Colonial Railway Station has now been undated with more space for travellers to embark and disembark.   Prominent spot in the Ella Town
Very pleasant holiday. Such a journey. Amazing views. Food and drinks are possible to buy at the train during many times. Cool cabins.

The infamous Sri Lankan train journey. Most people have probably seen the pictures of packed trains with people hanging out of them. If you fear this, don’t. The train you will likely be getting will be full of tourists also and is not overcrowded at all. You will pass the tea plantations, the jungles, the mountains, the local villages, and get to see a large portion of the beauty of Sri Lanka in one trip. For those who like the thrill of adventure, you can sit in the open carriage door and get to feel the wind in your face as you breeze through the countryside. It has a certain romance about it and feels like the stories about train journeys in the early 20th century when exploring was taking off.

As you step on/ step off your train, do take a moment to soak in the colonial past left behind by the British. In contrast to other train stations, Ella is well looked after and preserved. Apart from that, remember to hand in your ticket and enjoy Ella.... Unless you're departing - then hope you enjoyed Ella.
definitely do not miss this train trip from Kandy to Ella. it 7 hours which definitely worth it. Can not miss it

We arrived in Ella by train, and left by train. But we also visited it twice during various treks along the railway line (it's OK, everybody does it, not least, the locals!). The station is beautifully tended, including lovely flower beds. If you're British, and getting on a bit, you will be reminded of a typical BR branch-line station of yesteryear, complete with UK-pattern semaphore signals. So nostalgic!

The Ella railway station is well looked after with flowers like many of the Sri Lankan stations. It is quaint and very fitting for the epic train journey from here to Kandy though the tea country. Service at the ticket counter was friendly.

Ella is obviously taking care of this railway station. It is nicely made up and makes you feel transported back in time. When you arrive there with a train from Nuwara Eliya say it´s gonna be a little bit busy, but it is still nice to go for a walk there and have a look see.
We caught the train from Nuwara Eliya to Ella.  Travelling on the mountain side looking out over tea plantations and stopping for locals to board and alight.  A real unbelievable journey.
Well marked, no problem getting assistance! Lacking seating but I think this is standard in Sri Lanka!

The station is a quaint old building that was probably built during colonial times. There is only one platform where the trains come and go. Take a look round and you will see old winches and other equipment that have been there for years.

The station was lovely and pretty - flowers everywhere, most of the stations are well cared for and have beautiful roses, lillies etc decorating the platform.  The journey from Ella to Kandy was extremely long, 7 hours.  We travelled in second class, which was a mistake, if I went again, I would travel in economy.  The doors were closed and locked in first class and when we I asked if we could have them opened, the guard opened them but asked for a 'gift' - so in other words, the guards were asking for money from first and second class passengers!!!  When you looked out of the window, down the train, you could see that all the doors were open and everyone was sitting with their feet dangling out of the train - free!  As those doors were always unlocked. Later, when I hadn't given him a gift, he locked the door of the train and never returned to reopen it.  Oh well, I had a great 20 minutes whizzing past all the beautiful scenery bare footed!  Throughout the journey, many salespeople boarded the train with welcome food, drink and snacks.  The food was mainly sandwiches, curried eggs and samosas quite nice and kept us going. I would have rated the station itself higher, but I would have rated the journey and the feeling of being taken advantage of, lower.
The station is very well maintained winning awards. Lovely gardens around, clean & picturesque ! Station master has been [rightfully] awarded.
Stand back when the train arrives from Colombo, The nuber of travellers getting off is huge. But treat yoursel to a trip to Badulla and back, What a fantastic journey

We decided to travel against the crowds and go from Ella Station to Nanuoya. We were glad we did as the train was only half full and we were able to get top window seats and for most of the journey a spot in the doorway looking right out over the landscape. Tips: 1. When travelling toward Colombo try get a seat on the right side of the train, much better views than the left side of the train. 2. Forget first class, the windows don’t open and the AC on our trained was poor. 3. If u like the fresh air try get a doorway vantage point ASAP. To avoid losing your spot bring your jumper as the further u go toward Nanuoya the cooler it gets.
Staff are very helpful, short walk to the 9 arches bridge, short walk to the start of Ella's peak. Bit of a mad rush when you get off so hold on tight to your loved ones and bags!
We arrived here by train after a three hour ride across the heart of the tea country. We would recommend to maybe start here and go in the other direction as ours was so crowded.

Ohiya is merely a railway station and a few small shops in the middle of the hill country of Sri Lanka. It's a beautiful place, but please ensure you have booked accommodation and travel arrangements before you arrive there. It is the best place to access Horton Plains National Park if you are travelling by train.

We were due to board the train to take us from Ella to Nuwara Eliya and our driver had secured our tickets-but that was just the start of it! The station was packed! And everyone wanted a seat on that train! I shoved my husband forwards and hung on to his coat tails as the train approached. We managed to board but seats had been “reserved” by one Russian lady who seemed to think that water bottles and baseball caps retained seats! There was a bit of a fracas when we removed said objects and informed her that in Yorkshire it’s bums that secure seats-and so we sat down! This is considered to be “one of the scenic railway journeys in the world” and I can well believe it. It’s an absolutely jaw dropping sight with huge sweeping mountains; small, busy villages; stunning areas of protected areas; until you reach the swathes and swathes of tea plantations which totally cover the mountains. An absolute must!

Although the Rail Station doesn't have a proper washroom an ATM nearby is helpful.  Have Fun ....... The Olive trees attract numerous migrating birds and plenty of roses are welcoming ..... An additional platform to receive travelers would enhance facilities ....

Caught a train from here to Badula town, about 45 mins and a great way to see the countryside, including 9 arches bridge. 20 rupees each way in 3rd class and great fun with the locals coming back in the dark and arriving at Ella in a siding not at a platform as the Blue train was expected and we had to climb down onto the track... so exciting. The other stations along the way are so old fashioned it's like stepping back in time.
A small railway station, well maintained.Visited for curiosity. The road leading to the station was very bad, full of mud due to rain.

We took the train from Ella to Demodara from this station. It has a real old world charm about it. Place was exceptionally clean and comfortable. Staff were very friendly and helpful,ever willing to help us with information and useful tips! Love this place...

Ella station is so pretty and clean.They take pride in their station and it shows with the gardens.Good idea is to buy your rail tickets a day in advance as there are long queues for trains on the day
This is a well preserved railway station, worth a visit as it is located in the town of Ella and easy to get to. The train ride to this spot is supposed to be one of the best in the world.

This is one of the best railway stations in Sri Lanka. The the surrounding lovely a well maintained flower garden. The station master is well dressed in real English style clothing. Staff is very friendly and helpful This place is a very good example for all the other railway stations.
Lovely little place that reminds you of old world. Very English countryside!! One can go there just to see it from outside.

Sri Lanka Railways are like a step back in time but in a good way. I loved Ella station but then all the stations on the Ella - Nuwarya Eliya line are like mini postcards, all the station masters dress like admirals and the stations look like the English country railway stations you see in old black and white movies. The trains are slow but hey, we're all here on holiday, so what's the rush?

Taking the train from Ella can be long (depending on where you're going) but the station is efficient and clean, and not a bad place to hang out for half an hour (clean bathrooms!!). The station is convenient, and staff is friendly and all speak English.

Ella is a famous location in Sri Lanka which is in Uva Province of the country. Accessing by Train is a good mode choice. Nearest tourist attraction locations are Ella Rock, Nine Arch Bridge Demodara, Mini Adam's peak and Ella water fall. These are common tourist attraction areas in Ella. But apart form this Blackpool is nice river runs in that area to visit and have bath. But be careful. little dangerous.
The trains stop here.  You also need to go here, more or less, to walk to Ella Rock or the train bridge.

Dont miss this if you are in Ella. One of the best scenic rides that nature can offer. The train is very clean and plenty of space. Don't unnecessarily book the first and second class tickets. Its an overkill. Make advance seat reservations in a 3rd class coach. It offers open windows which is a great experience as compared to the closed down windows of the 1st and 2nd class coaches.
We caught a train from Ella to Habutale. It was a lovely experience, the views were amazing, the service was great and trains on time. I would recommended for anyone.

The signal box we looked at was made in Chippenham, Wiltshire in 1857 ..... and still working, the trains are "new" and Chinese but a great thing to do. The stations are a snapshot of colonial times Glad we did it.

This is probably one of the best railway stations in Sri Lanka. First of all the surrounding is picturesque. There is a well maintained flowery garden. Cleanliness is very high too. Staff is very friendly and even suggest what to do best , as which train will be ideal or if we are able to have seats etc. This place is a shining example for all the other railway stations.
One of the efficent Railway Station in Srilanka.  The maintenance of the place is perfect and mostly the service is outstanding

Stayed overnight in Ella before catching the 6.4O train to Nuwellia. We caught the blue train travelling first class.The carriages were comfortable and snacks and drinks were served.On the journey we went through several tunnels and the scenery was beautiful and green. The journey lasted about two hours and we enjoyed every minute enjoying the scenery and calling at several stations on route.It was a welcome change from the heat of the coast.We travelled with Raj of See Lanka travel who wa# an excellent guide pointing out places of interest on route.
